articles.headline: On the House Floor, Republicans Gag Mentions of Trump’s Conviction
articles.snippet: During official proceedings of the G.O.P.-controlled chamber, speaking about former President Donald J. Trump’s felony conviction has been forbidden, while disparaging President Biden and Democrats is routine.
articles.abstract: During official proceedings of the G.O.P.-controlled chamber, speaking about former President Donald J. Trump’s felony conviction has been forbidden, while disparaging President Biden and Democrats is routine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The floor of the United States House of Representatives is supposed to be a dignified place, where lawmakers refer to each other as “gentleman” or “gentle lady,” speak only to the presiding officer, and never engage in personally disparaging remarks against rivals, an offense known as “engaging in personalities.”

articles.headline: It’s Fine if Investing Bores You. Some Money Pros Feel the Same Way.
articles.snippet: For many financial professionals, investing is just a tool to help people achieve their meaningful life goals.
articles.abstract: For many financial professionals, investing is just a tool to help people achieve their meaningful life goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a certain type of money professional, there is a particular question that is decidedly unwelcome, and it tends to come up in a variety of social settings: Got any hot investment tips?

articles.headline: How Mark Zuckerberg’s Meta Failed Children on Safety, States Say
articles.snippet: The C.E.O. and his team drove Meta’s efforts to capture young users and misled the public about the risks, lawsuits by state attorneys general say.
articles.abstract: The C.E.O. and his team drove Meta’s efforts to capture young users and misled the public about the risks, lawsuits by state attorneys general say.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April 2019, David Ginsberg, a Meta executive, emailed his boss, Mark Zuckerberg, with a proposal to research and reduce loneliness and compulsive use on Instagram and Facebook.

articles.headline: The Insiders: The 3 Men at the Core of Biden’s Brain Trust
articles.snippet: President Biden has a diverse group of advisers, but few have the influence of three men in his inner circle during his final campaign.
articles.abstract: President Biden has a diverse group of advisers, but few have the influence of three men in his inner circle during his final campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Multiple times each day, President Biden dials up Mike Donilon, a close adviser since the 1980s, to chew on the latest polls and headlines.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: These Grieving Parents Want Congress to Protect Children Online
articles.snippet: A group is using the Mothers Against Drunk Driving playbook, sharing personal tragedies, to lobby for the Kids Online Safety Act.
articles.abstract: A group is using the Mothers Against Drunk Driving playbook, sharing personal tragedies, to lobby for the Kids Online Safety Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deb Schmill has become a fixture on Capitol Hill. Last week alone, she visited the offices of 13 lawmakers, one of more than a dozen trips she has made from her home near Boston over the past two years.

articles.headline: What the Arrival of A.I. Phones and Computers Means for Our Data
articles.snippet: Apple, Microsoft and Google need more access to our data as they promote new phones and personal computers that are powered by artificial intelligence. Should we trust them?
articles.abstract: Apple, Microsoft and Google need more access to our data as they promote new phones and personal computers that are powered by artificial intelligence. Should we trust them?
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple, Microsoft and Google are heralding a new era of what they describe as artificially intelligent smartphones and computers. The devices, they say, will automate tasks like editing photos and wishing a friend a happy birthday.

articles.headline: The Nation Resurgent, and Borders, Too
articles.snippet: In France, as in the United States, feelings harden against immigrants, and President Emmanuel Macron and President Biden take note.
articles.abstract: In France, as in the United States, feelings harden against immigrants, and President Emmanuel Macron and President Biden take note.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the heart of the rapid rise of the nationalist right, with its view of immigrants as a direct threat to the essence of France, there appears to lie a growing feeling among many French people that they are no longer at home in their own country.

articles.headline: For Biden and Trump, a Debate Rematch With Even Greater Risks and Rewards
articles.snippet: The matchup on Thursday will be the earliest presidential debate in American history, and any potential missteps could linger for weeks or months.
articles.abstract: The matchup on Thursday will be the earliest presidential debate in American history, and any potential missteps could linger for weeks or months.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debate between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump this week will be the highest-stakes moment of their rematch, plunging two presidents into an extraordinarily early confrontation before a divided and angry nation.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Blaming Hamas for Gazans’ Suffering, Many Israelis Feel Little Sympathy
articles.snippet: Despite being aware of the devastation in the enclave, many in Israel ask why they should show pity when Palestinians there showed none on Oct. 7.
articles.abstract: Despite being aware of the devastation in the enclave, many in Israel ask why they should show pity when Palestinians there showed none on Oct. 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: The southern Israeli city of Netivot, a working-class hub for mystical rabbis about 10 miles from the Gaza border, escaped the worst of the Hamas-led attack of Oct. 7, a fluke many residents ascribe to miraculous intervention by the Jewish sages buried here.

articles.headline: Child Care, Cafes, Herman Miller Desks: It’s Not Your Average Gym
articles.snippet: High-end gyms, many of which used to be an amenity, are now the star attraction, offering hotel rooms and workspaces as part of their appeal. They’ve also gotten a lot bigger.
articles.abstract: High-end gyms, many of which used to be an amenity, are now the star attraction, offering hotel rooms and workspaces as part of their appeal. They’ve also gotten a lot bigger.
articles.lead_paragraph: High-end gyms are no longer just places to sweat it out.

articles.headline: Michael Flynn Has Turned His Trump-World Celebrity Into a Family Business
articles.snippet: The former national security adviser took over a nonprofit group. Soon, it was paying five of his relatives and trafficking in conspiracy theories.
articles.abstract: The former national security adviser took over a nonprofit group. Soon, it was paying five of his relatives and trafficking in conspiracy theories.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2021, retired Gen. Michael T. Flynn, Donald J. Trump’s first national security adviser, became chairman of a 75-year-old nonprofit organization — the kind of small charity where chairmen typically work for free.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: Pilgrim Deaths in Mecca Put Spotlight on Underbelly of Hajj Industry
articles.snippet: More than 1,300 people died, and a Saudi official said most of them were not registered for the pilgrimage. That left them with little protection from the heat.
articles.abstract: More than 1,300 people died, and a Saudi official said most of them were not registered for the pilgrimage. That left them with little protection from the heat.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 1,300 people died making the Islamic pilgrimage of hajj in Saudi Arabia this month, the vast majority of whom the Saudi government said did not have permits. Many walked for miles in scorching heat after paying thousands of dollars to illicit or fraudulent tour operators.
articles.byline: By Emad Mekay and Vivian Nereim

articles.headline: Japan and South Korea Are Fighting Over an App at a Tense Time
articles.snippet: SoftBank and Naver helped bridge geopolitical relations with a joint venture to own the operator of the messaging app Line, but now the partnership is fraying.
articles.abstract: SoftBank and Naver helped bridge geopolitical relations with a joint venture to own the operator of the messaging app Line, but now the partnership is fraying.
articles.lead_paragraph: A joint venture set up in 2019 by two top Japanese and South Korean companies was hailed as a beacon of cooperation amid strained diplomatic relations.

articles.headline: In This Debate, CNN Is the Decider
articles.snippet: One network is in charge of every aspect of the Biden-Trump debate, a major shift from previous years. Tens of millions of viewers are expected to be watching.
articles.abstract: One network is in charge of every aspect of the Biden-Trump debate, a major shift from previous years. Tens of millions of viewers are expected to be watching.
articles.lead_paragraph: The prime-time matchup on Thursday between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump represents an evening full of promise and peril.

articles.headline: Apple Is First Company Charged Under New E.U. Competition Law
articles.snippet: The company’s App Store policies are illegal under the European Union’s Digital Markets Act, according to regulators in Brussels.
articles.abstract: The company’s App Store policies are illegal under the European Union’s Digital Markets Act, according to regulators in Brussels.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple is imposing unfair restrictions on developers of applications for its App Store in violation of a new European Union law meant to encourage competition in the tech industry, regulators in Brussels said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Abortion Debate Shifts as Election Nears: ‘Now It’s About Pregnancy’
articles.snippet: Two years after Roe was struck down, the conversation has focused on the complications that can come with pregnancy and fertility, helping to drive more support for abortion rights.
articles.abstract: Two years after Roe was struck down, the conversation has focused on the complications that can come with pregnancy and fertility, helping to drive more support for abortion rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the decades that Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, abortion rights groups tried to shore up support for it by declaring “Abortion Is Health Care.”

articles.headline: Iran’s Onerous Hijab Law for Women Is Now a Campaign Issue
articles.snippet: In a sign that a women-led movement has gained ground, all of the men running for president have distanced themselves from the harsh tactics used to enforce mandatory hijab.
articles.abstract: In a sign that a women-led movement has gained ground, all of the men running for president have distanced themselves from the harsh tactics used to enforce mandatory hijab.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iranian officials insisted for decades that the law requiring women to cover their hair and dress modestly was sacrosanct and not even worth discussion. They dismissed the struggle by women who challenged the law as a symptom of Western meddling.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar

articles.headline: ‘It’s All Happening Again.’ The Supply Chain Is Under Strain.
articles.snippet: As Houthi rebels intensify strikes on vessels headed for the Suez Canal, global shipping prices are soaring, raising fears of product shortages and delays.
articles.abstract: As Houthi rebels intensify strikes on vessels headed for the Suez Canal, global shipping prices are soaring, raising fears of product shortages and delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephanie Loomis had hoped that the chaos besieging the global supply chain was subsiding. The floating traffic jams off ports. The multiplying costs of moving freight. The resulting shortages of goods. All of this had seemed like an unpleasant memory confined to the Covid-19 pandemic.

articles.headline: Fearing Losses, Banks Are Quietly Dumping Real Estate Loans
articles.snippet: If landlords can’t pay back loans on office buildings, the lenders will suffer. Some banks are trying to avoid that fate.
articles.abstract: If landlords can’t pay back loans on office buildings, the lenders will suffer. Some banks are trying to avoid that fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some Wall Street banks, worried that landlords of vacant and struggling office buildings won’t be able to pay off their mortgages, have begun offloading their portfolios of commercial real estate loans hoping to cut their losses.

articles.headline: C.E.O.s Are Frustrated. That Doesn’t Mean They Embrace Trump.
articles.snippet: Corporate executives complain about some of President Biden’s policies, along with his rhetoric. But so far they have not abandoned him en masse.
articles.abstract: Corporate executives complain about some of President Biden’s policies, along with his rhetoric. But so far they have not abandoned him en masse.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the White House chief of staff, Jeffrey Zients, met with dozens of top executives in Washington this month, he encountered a familiar list of corporate complaints about President Biden.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Jim Tankersley, Sydney Ember and Theodore Schleifer
